bestBHT.bht: In times past, the Gentiles disobeyed God, but now, through the disobedience of the Jews, they have obtained mercy. The mercy shown to the Gentiles is an opportunity for the Jews to also receive mercy. This transformation from disbelief to receiving mercy is emphasized, as the Gentiles once did not believe but have now obtained mercy. The repetition of the word now underscores the current reality of this mercy, emphasizing the profound change that has occurred.

Henry Alford: For as ye in times past were disobedient to God, but now by the disobedience of these, have obtained mercy."  (31 words)
Even so have these also now been disobedient, that by the mercy shewn to you, they also may obtain mercy."  (23 words)
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: For as ye in times past have not believed, yet now have obtained mercy through their unbelief."
Not believed... yet now have obtained mercy."
Now... obtained mercy through their unbelief.
Albert Barnes: This refers to the former idolatrous and sinful state of the pagan world.
Philip Schaff: Ye, Gentiles, were once disobedient to God.
All their blessings as Christians are summed up as the result of the mercy of Him to whom they had been disobedient.
Their ‘unbelief’ is however characterized here as ‘disobedience.’
Archibald T. Robertson: Ye once upon a time disobeyed God.
Note 'now' three times in this sentence.
John Gill: The times referred to, are the times of ignorance, idolatry, and superstition; when God suffered the Gentiles, for many hundreds of years, to walk in their own ways.

They either, as some of them, did not believe there was a God, or that there was but one God, at least but very few believed it; and these did not know who he was; nor did they glorify him as God, or perform any true spiritual worship to him.
The unbelief of the Jews was the occasion and means, in Providence, of bringing the Gospel to the Gentiles, whereby faith came.

bhtAttempts.bht: In Romans 11:30, the apostle Paul addresses the contrast between the past disobedience of the Gentiles and the present mercy they have received, highlighting the interconnectedness of their salvation with the disobedience of the Jews. The verse emphasizes the Gentiles' transformation from a state of disbelief to obtaining mercy, underscoring the significance of their newfound faith. By referencing the disobedience of these (referring to the Jews), the verse suggests that the mercy extended to the Gentiles serves as an opportunity for the Jews to also obtain mercy. The repetition of the word now underscores the present reality of the mercy that both groups have experienced.

In the past, the Gentiles disobeyed God, but now they have obtained mercy through their unbelief. This verse emphasizes the connection between the Gentiles' salvation and the disobedience of the Jews. By mentioning the disobedience of these (referring to the Jews), it suggests that the mercy shown to the Gentiles opens an opportunity for the Jews to also receive mercy. The repetition of the word now highlights the present reality of the mercy experienced by both groups.

In the past, the Gentiles were disobedient to God, but now they have obtained mercy. This mercy is a result of the Jews' disobedience and serves as an opportunity for them to also receive mercy. The Gentiles, who once did not believe, have experienced a radical shift and are now recipients of mercy. The repetition of the word now underscores the present reality of this mercy, highlighting the transformation that has taken place.

In times past, the Gentiles disobeyed God, but now, through the disobedience of the Jews, they have obtained mercy. The mercy shown to the Gentiles is an opportunity for the Jews to also receive mercy. This transformation from disbelief to receiving mercy is emphasized, as the Gentiles once did not believe but have now obtained mercy. The repetition of the word now underscores the current reality of this mercy, emphasizing the profound change that has occurred.

In times past, the Gentiles were disobedient to God, but now, by the disobedience of the Jews, they have obtained mercy. The mercy shown to the Gentiles is an opportunity for the Jews to also obtain mercy. This verse emphasizes the Gentiles' transformation from unbelief to receiving mercy. The repetition of the word now underscores the present reality of this mercy, highlighting the significant change that has taken place. The disobedience of the Jews serves as a means through which the Gentiles have received the blessings of faith.
